quiz.title: Unit 7: Labor Markets (Quiz 6)
quiz.subtitle: 7.6 Labor Market Equilibrium: Wage and Employment Determination (20 Questions)
quiz.subject: Economics
quiz.topic: Labor Market Equilibrium, Wage Determination, Employment Levels, Market Clearing

questions.question: In a competitive labor market, equilibrium occurs where:
questions.explanation: In competitive equilibrium, labor demand = labor supply, wage = MRP (for firms), and quantity demanded = quantity supplied.

questions.question: The equilibrium wage in a competitive labor market is determined by:
options: The intersection of labor demand and supply curves
questions.explanation: In competitive markets, the equilibrium wage and employment level are found where the labor demand and supply curves intersect.

questions.question: If the market wage is above the equilibrium wage, there will be:
questions.explanation: When wage > equilibrium, quantity supplied exceeds quantity demanded, creating unemployment (labor surplus).

questions.question: At the competitive equilibrium wage, all workers hired have MRP:
questions.explanation: Firms hire until MRP = wage, so the marginal worker's MRP equals the wage, though inframarginal workers have MRP > wage.

questions.question: An increase in labor productivity would cause equilibrium:
options: Wage and employment to both decrease
Wage and employment to both increase
Wage to increase but employment to decrease
Wage to decrease but employment to increase
questions.explanation: Higher productivity shifts labor demand rightward, increasing both the equilibrium wage and employment level.

questions.question: If immigration increases the labor supply, the equilibrium:
questions.explanation: Increased labor supply shifts the supply curve rightward, lowering the equilibrium wage but increasing employment.

questions.question: On a labor market graph, total wage payments are represented by:
options: The area under the demand curve
The area under the supply curve
The triangle between demand and supply
questions.explanation: Total wage bill = equilibrium wage × equilibrium employment, which is the area of the rectangle from origin to equilibrium point.

questions.question: Worker surplus in labor market equilibrium is the area:
options: Above the wage and below the demand curve
Below the wage and above the supply curve
questions.explanation: Worker surplus = area below the wage line and above the supply curve, representing the difference between wages received and reservation wages.

questions.question: Employer surplus in labor market equilibrium is the area:
options: Above the wage and below the demand curve
Below the wage and above the supply curve
questions.explanation: Employer surplus = area above the wage line and below the demand curve, representing the difference between MRP and wages paid.

questions.question: A minimum wage set above the equilibrium wage creates:
questions.explanation: A binding minimum wage creates a surplus of labor (unemployment) because quantity supplied exceeds quantity demanded at that wage.

questions.question: The deadweight loss from a binding minimum wage is represented by:
options: The triangle between demand and supply for unemployed workers
The transfer from employers to workers
questions.explanation: Deadweight loss is the triangle between demand and supply curves for the employment reduction, representing lost gains from trade.

questions.question: In a monopsony labor market, the equilibrium wage is:
options: The same as in perfect competition
questions.explanation: Monopsonists pay lower wages and employ fewer workers than would occur in competitive markets.

questions.question: Labor market equilibrium is efficient when:
options: MRP = wage for the last worker hired
questions.explanation: Efficiency requires that the value of the marginal worker's output (MRP) equals the opportunity cost of their time (wage).

questions.question: An economic recession typically causes labor market equilibrium to shift toward:
questions.explanation: Recessions reduce labor demand, shifting the demand curve leftward, lowering both equilibrium wage and employment.

questions.question: If both labor demand and supply increase, equilibrium employment will:
questions.explanation: Both shifts increase equilibrium employment unambiguously, though the wage effect depends on the relative magnitude of shifts.

questions.question: The 'market-clearing wage' refers to the wage that:
questions.explanation: The market-clearing wage is the equilibrium wage where labor demand equals labor supply, with no involuntary unemployment.

questions.question: In long-run competitive equilibrium, workers earn:
options: Less than competitive firms would pay
questions.explanation: In long-run equilibrium, workers earn wages equal to their opportunity cost (reservation wage), with no economic rent unless they have unique skills.

questions.question: Labor market frictions (like search costs) can cause:
options: The equilibrium to occur more quickly
Persistent unemployment even at market-clearing wages
Wages to always be above equilibrium
questions.explanation: Search and matching frictions mean that even at the market-clearing wage, it takes time for workers and employers to find each other, creating frictional unemployment.

questions.question: If labor demand is perfectly inelastic, an increase in labor supply will:
options: Increase employment but not change wages
Decrease wages but not change employment
questions.explanation: With perfectly inelastic demand, employment is fixed, so increased supply only lowers wages without changing employment.

questions.question: The total economic surplus in labor market equilibrium is maximized when:
options: Wages are as high as possible
Employment is as high as possible
questions.explanation: Competitive equilibrium maximizes the sum of worker and employer surplus, achieving allocative efficiency in the labor market.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You thoroughly understand labor market equilibrium, wage determination, and how various factors affect employment.
scoreMessages.70: Good work! You understand the basics but should review how demand and supply shifts affect equilibrium, and the effects of market interventions.
scoreMessages.50: A fair start. Focus on: how equilibrium wage and employment are determined, reading labor market graphs, and effects of minimum wages.
scoreMessages.0: Keep practicing! Remember that labor market equilibrium occurs where demand equals supply, determining both wages and employment levels.
